title: Democrats threaten White House with new subpoena on Ukraine documents
text:
The subpoena threat came just minutes before Speaker Nancy Pelosi and House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) were set to speak at a news conference about House Democrats’ impeachment inquiry, which is focused on Trump’s July 25 phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. During that call, Trump pressured Zelensky to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a potential political rival in the 2020 campaign.

Giuliani was served with a subpoena earlier this week, and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is under subpoena to produce documents about State Department officials’ communications with Giuliani.

On Tuesday, Pompeo sent a letter to House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Eliot Engel (D-N.Y.) accusing House Democrats of trying to bully and intimidate him and other senior State Department officials with a broad request for information related to Trump’s efforts to solicit foreign help in investigating Biden and his son, Hunter.

Pompeo indicated that he would not comply with Engel’s subpoena, which has a Friday deadline and was issued in conjunction with the Intelligence and Oversight panels.

Pompeo also said a proposed schedule of depositions with current and former State Department officials was “not feasible.” But at least two of them — former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch and former U.S. Special Envoy for Ukraine Kurt Volker — will appear for their depositions, according to a congressional aide. Volker’s interview is still scheduled for Thursday, while Yovanovitch will appear on Oct. 11.

Earlier Wednesday, Pompeo confirmed news reports that he listened in on Trump’s phone call with Zelensky. The conversation is the subject of a whistleblower complaint that the Trump administration initially withheld from the congressional intelligence committees.

The timing of Pelosi’s news conference was unusual given that it came during a scheduled two-week congressional recess. But it reflects an effort by Democratic leaders to help rank-and-file lawmakers — in particular, moderates and those who come from GOP-leaning districts — craft a consistent message as House investigators press forward with an impeachment inquiry.

Pelosi and her leadership team have promised regular caucus calls over the break to ensure Democrats are kept in the loop about ongoing developments. There’s a caucus call planned for Wednesday afternoon at the same time Trump is scheduled to hold a press conference at the White House.

On a call with the caucus on Sunday, Pelosi and other senior Democrats laid out their strategy to win the impeachment messaging war: repeatedly hammer Trump’s alleged misdeeds and avoid getting distracted by trying to refute GOP talking points.

House investigators could glean also new information related to their Ukraine probe later Wednesday when Steve Linick, the State Department’s inspector general, briefs House and Senate committee staffers. Linick requested the briefing shortly after Pompeo’s letter was released on Tuesday, saying it was an “urgent” matter.
